item.title: Distance Metrics and Beyond
item.description: Getting Started A distance function(also referred as a metric) in mathematics refers to the function that defines a distance between any two points of a set. The most prevalent example is the Euclidean distance. But let’s first define what makes a function a distance function. For a function to be a distance function, it has to satisfy the following properties$^{[1]}$ : Non-negativity : $d(x, y) \geq 0$ Identity : $d(x, y) = 0 \iff x=y$ Symmetry : $d(x, y) = d(y, x)$ Triangle Inequality : $d(x, z) \leq d(x, y) + d(y, z)$ Some of the distance functions which we went over in class were $L_p$ distances, Jaccard Distance, Cosine Distance and Edit distance.
